question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Simplify $(a-1)(a+1)(a+2) - (a-2)(a+1).$
inference:
$$(a-1)(a+1)(a+2) - (a-2)(a+1)$$
$$=(a^2-1)(a+2) - (a^2-2a+a-2) \qquad \text{ [Since } (a-b)(a+b)=a^2-b^2 \text{ ]}$$
$$=a^3+2a^2-a-2-(a^2-a-2) \qquad \text{ [Distributing]}$$
$$=a^3+a^2-a \qquad \text{ [Simplifying]}$$
$$=a(a^2+a-1) \qquad \text{ [Factoring out a common factor a]}$$
$$=a(a-1)(a+1) \qquad \text{ [Factoring the quadratic]}$$

Final Answer: $\boxed{a(a-1)(a+1)}.$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
We successively expand by multiplying binomials: \begin{align*}
(a&-1)(a+1)(a+2) - (a-2)(a+1)\\
&= (a^2-1)(a+2)-(a-2)(a+1)\\
&= (a^3 + 2a^2 - a - 2) - (a^2 -a -2)\\
&= a^3 + a^2.
\end{align*}So our answer is just $\boxed{a^3 + a^2}$.

$$=a^3+a^2-a \qquad \text{ [Simplifying]}$$
$$=a(a^2+a-1) \qquad \text{ [Factoring out a common factor a]}$$
$$=a(a-1)(a+1) \qquad \text{ [Factoring the quadratic]}$$

Final Answer: $\boxed{a(a-1)(a+1)}.$ I hope it is correct.
